xxl.core.functions
Class AbstractFunction<P,R>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.functions.AbstractFunction<P,R>
Type Parameters:
P - the type of the function's parameters.
R - the return type of the function.
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, Function<P,R>
Direct Known Subclasses:
AbstractMetaDataFunction, AbstractRealFunctionFunction, AdaBandKernelDensityEstimatorND, AggregationFunctionFunction, ArrayFactory, Column, Constant, DecoratorArrayFunction, FastMapProjection, For.IntegerIncrement, Identity, Iff, MultiPrint, NTuplify, PredicateFunction, Print, Projection, Projection, RandomAccessFileQueue.InputStreamFactory, RandomAccessFileQueue.OutputStreamFactory, RealFunctionFunction, Switch, Tuplify
public abstract class AbstractFunction<P,R>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Function<P,R>, java.io.Serializable

This class provides an abstract implementation of the interface Function. In order to declare a function as an object of class AbstractFunction, the invoke method has to be overridden. This method accepts both separate input parameters and a typed list holding them. The output of invoke is an object of the given return type. Simplified versions of invoke exists suitable for functions with none, one or two input parameters. It is important to mention that in general only one of the invoke methods has to be overridden. The invocation of a function is then triggered by simply calling invoke.

In combination with the powerful mechanism of anonymous classes, it is also possible to build higher-order functions which is known from functional programming (e. g. Haskel). The method compose shows how to declare a function h which consists of g o (f1,...,fn) where g is a function with n arguments and f1,...,fn are functions with an equal number of arguments. Note that compose provides the declaration of the function and does not execute the function.

Consider for example (see also the main-method) that you are interested in building the function tan which can be build by composing division and (sin, cos). Function div, sin, cos; 

   // Initialization of your functional objects
   ...
   // Declaration of a new function
   Function<Double, Double> tan = Functions.compose(div, sin, cos);
   ...
   // Execution of the new function
   tan.invoke(x);

Method Detail

invoke

public R invoke(java.util.List<? extends P> arguments)
         throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
Returns the result of the function as an object of the return type. This method determines arguments.size() and calls the appropriate invoke method (see below). The other invoke methods call this method. This means, that the user either has to override this method or one (!) of the other invoke methods. If null is given as argument invoke((P)null) will be returned meaning invoke(P) is needed to be overridden.

Implementation: 

   if (arguments == null)
       return invoke((P)null);
   switch (arguments.size()) {
       case 0:
           return invoke();
       case 1:
           return invoke(arguments.get(0));
       case 2:
           return invoke(arguments.get(0), arguments.get(1));
       default:
           throw new IllegalStateException("R invoke(List<? super P>) has to be overridden! The number of arguments was " + arguments.size() + ".");
   }

Specified by:
invoke in interface Function<P,R>
Parameters:
arguments - a list of the arguments to the function.
Returns:
the function value is returned.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a list of arguments is given that contains 3 or more arguments and the corresponding method R invoke(List<? extends P>) has not been overridden.
